title: Psalms Chapter 93 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Psalms chapter 93 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Psalms Chapter 93 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Psalms Chapter 93.

questions.question: According to Psalms 93:1, what is the LORD clothed with?
questions.correctAnswer: Majesty and strength
questions.explanation: Psalms 93:1 states the LORD is clothed with majesty and strength.

questions.question: What does Psalms 93:2 say about the throne of the LORD?
questions.correctAnswer: It is established of old
questions.explanation: Psalms 93:2 says, 'Thy throne is established of old.'

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 93:4 says the LORD on high is mightier than the noise of many waters.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 93:4 confirms the LORD is mightier than the noise of many waters.

questions.question: What have the floods done according to Psalms 93:3?
options: Lifted up their voice and waves
questions.correctAnswer: Lifted up their voice and waves
questions.explanation: Psalms 93:3 states the floods have lifted up their voice and waves.

questions.question: Fill in the blank from Psalms 93:5: "Thy testimonies are very sure: holiness becometh thine ______, O LORD, for ever."
questions.correctAnswer: house
questions.explanation: Psalms 93:5 says holiness becometh thine house, O LORD.

questions.question: According to Psalms 93:1, what has the LORD girded himself with?
questions.correctAnswer: Strength
questions.explanation: Psalms 93:1 states the LORD is clothed with strength, wherewith he hath girded himself.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 93:2 says the LORD is from everlasting.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 93:2 describes the LORD as from everlasting.

questions.question: What is said about the world in Psalms 93:1?
options: It is stablished and cannot be moved
It is fragile and moves often
It is hidden from the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: It is stablished and cannot be moved
questions.explanation: Psalms 93:1 states the world also is stablished, that it cannot be moved.

questions.question: According to Psalms 93:4, what is the LORD mightier than?
questions.correctAnswer: The noise of many waters
questions.explanation: Psalms 93:4 says the LORD on high is mightier than the noise of many waters.

questions.question: What does Psalms 93:3 mention that the floods have done?
options: Lifted up their voice and waves
questions.correctAnswer: Lifted up their voice and waves
questions.explanation: Psalms 93:3 describes the floods lifting up their voice and waves.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 93:5 says holiness becometh the LORD's house forever.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Psalms 93:5 states holiness becometh thine house, O LORD, for ever.

questions.question: What is the LORD described as being clothed with in Psalms 93:1?
questions.correctAnswer: Majesty and strength
questions.explanation: Psalms 93:1 describes the LORD as clothed with majesty and strength.

questions.question: According to Psalms 93:2, how old is the LORD's throne?
questions.correctAnswer: Established of old
questions.explanation: Psalms 93:2 says the throne is established of old.

questions.question: What does Psalms 93:5 say about the LORD's testimonies?
questions.correctAnswer: They are very sure
questions.explanation: Psalms 93:5 states that the LORD's testimonies are very sure.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: "The LORD on high is mightier than the noise of many ______." (Psalms 93:4)
questions.correctAnswer: waters
questions.explanation: Psalms 93:4 says the LORD on high is mightier than the noise of many waters.

medium.title: Psalms Chapter 93 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Psalms Chapter 93 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Psalms 93, what biblical truth would you share about God's sovereignty and strength?
options: God reigns with majesty and strength, unshaken by any circumstance.
God is distant and uninvolved in earthly matters.
God's power is limited compared to natural forces.
God changes His mind according to human needs.
questions.correctAnswer: God reigns with majesty and strength, unshaken by any circumstance.
questions.explanation: Psalms 93:1 teaches that the LORD reigns, clothed with majesty and strength, and that the world is firmly established and cannot be moved, showing God's sovereign power over all trials.

questions.question: How does Psalms 93:2 encourage believers to trust in God's eternal nature when facing uncertainty in life?
options: God's throne is established from everlasting, showing His eternal reign.
God's throne is temporary and subject to change.
God only reigns over certain nations.
God's power depends on human actions.
questions.correctAnswer: God's throne is established from everlasting, showing His eternal reign.
questions.explanation: Psalms 93:2 states that God's throne is established of old and that He is from everlasting, encouraging believers to trust in His unchanging and eternal sovereignty.

questions.question: A believer is overwhelmed by the chaos of life. Based on Psalms 93:3-4, what truth about God’s power can you share to encourage them?
options: God is mightier than the noise of many waters and mighty waves.
God is powerless against natural disasters.
Human strength is greater than God’s power.
Chaos is stronger than God’s control.
questions.correctAnswer: God is mightier than the noise of many waters and mighty waves.
questions.explanation: Psalms 93:3-4 describe floods and mighty waves lifting their voice, but affirm that the LORD on high is mightier, reassuring believers of God's supreme power over turmoil.

questions.question: How does Psalms 93:5 teach us about the importance of holiness in the life of a believer and the church?
options: Holiness becometh God's house forever, emphasizing purity in worship and community.
God accepts any behavior in His house.
Holiness is only for priests, not all believers.
questions.correctAnswer: Holiness becometh God's house forever, emphasizing purity in worship and community.
questions.explanation: Psalms 93:5 highlights that God's testimonies are sure and that holiness is fitting for His house forever, encouraging believers to pursue purity in personal and church life.

questions.question: A fellow believer is discouraged by shifting circumstances at work. Based on Psalms 93:1, what truth about God's stability can you share?
options: The world is established and cannot be moved, reflecting God's unchanging nature.
The world is unstable and God changes His plans frequently.
Change is always beyond God's control.
questions.correctAnswer: The world is established and cannot be moved, reflecting God's unchanging nature.
questions.explanation: Psalms 93:1 states the world is firmly established and cannot be moved, symbolizing God's steady and reliable nature in contrast to earthly instability.

questions.question: How does Psalms 93:2 inspire humility and contentment in believers regarding God's sovereignty?
options: Knowing God is from everlasting reminds believers to trust His eternal plan.
Believers should rely only on their own wisdom.
God's reign is temporary and uncertain.
Believers should seek to control God's throne.
questions.correctAnswer: Knowing God is from everlasting reminds believers to trust His eternal plan.
questions.explanation: Psalms 93:2 emphasizes that God's throne is established from everlasting, encouraging believers to humbly rest in His eternal wisdom and sovereignty.

questions.question: A church leader is teaching about perseverance through trials. Based on Psalms 93:3-4, what biblical truth supports enduring hardship?
options: Though floods lift their waves, the LORD is mightier and remains sovereign.
Trials are evidence that God has abandoned us.
The noise of troubles is stronger than God’s power.
We must face trials without trusting God.
questions.correctAnswer: Though floods lift their waves, the LORD is mightier and remains sovereign.
questions.explanation: Psalms 93:3-4 depict floods rising and making noise, but affirm the LORD's mightiness above them, teaching perseverance through trust in God's power.

questions.question: How does Psalms 93:5 encourage believers to maintain integrity and holiness in their daily lives?
options: God’s testimonies are sure and holiness befits His house forever, calling for consistent godly living.
Integrity is not necessary for pleasing God.
Holiness is only for special occasions.
questions.correctAnswer: God’s testimonies are sure and holiness befits His house forever, calling for consistent godly living.
questions.explanation: Psalms 93:5 teaches that God's testimonies are reliable and holiness is fitting for His house eternally, encouraging believers to live with integrity daily.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 93 assures us that no matter how chaotic life seems, God's power and reign are unshakeable.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The entire chapter, especially Psalms 93:1 and 93:4, confirms God's unshakable reign and might over chaos and natural forces.

questions.question: True or False: According to Psalms 93:2, God's throne is a recent establishment and may change over time.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 93:2 clearly states that God's throne is established of old and He is from everlasting, indicating permanence and eternal sovereignty.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: "The LORD reigneth, he is clothed with _______; the LORD is clothed with strength..." (Psalms 93:1)
questions.correctAnswer: majesty
questions.explanation: Psalms 93:1 states the LORD reigns and is clothed with majesty and strength, emphasizing God's majestic and powerful nature.

questions.question: How does Psalms 93:1-2 encourage believers in their prayer life and personal devotion?
options: By affirming God's eternal reign and unshakable throne, it motivates persistent trust and worship.
By suggesting God is distant and unapproachable.
By indicating prayer is unnecessary since God is unchanging.
By advising believers to pray only in times of trouble.
questions.correctAnswer: By affirming God's eternal reign and unshakable throne, it motivates persistent trust and worship.
questions.explanation: Verses 1 and 2 highlight God's majestic and eternal reign, encouraging believers to deepen their devotion and trust through prayer regardless of circumstances.

questions.question: A believer struggles with forgiveness and reconciliation. Based on Psalms 93:5, what principle can help encourage a holy lifestyle that fosters peace?
options: Holiness befits God's house forever, teaching us to pursue purity and peace in relationships.
Reconciliation is not related to holiness.
God does not require holiness in daily life.
questions.correctAnswer: Holiness befits God's house forever, teaching us to pursue purity and peace in relationships.
questions.explanation: Psalms 93:5 emphasizes the importance of holiness being fitting for God's house, which includes believers' lives, encouraging a lifestyle that supports forgiveness and peace.

questions.question: How does Psalms 93:3-4 provide hope for believers facing overwhelming pressures and temptations?
options: Though floods and waves are loud and strong, the LORD on high is mightier, assuring victory over trials.
Temptations are too strong to overcome.
Believers must rely solely on their own strength.
Pressure means God has abandoned us.
questions.correctAnswer: Though floods and waves are loud and strong, the LORD on high is mightier, assuring victory over trials.
questions.explanation: Verses 3-4 describe the power of floods and waves but affirm God's mightiness above them, giving hope that He empowers believers to overcome pressure and temptation.

questions.question: Based on Psalms 93:1, how can believers develop contentment and gratitude in their work ethic?
options: By trusting that God’s strength and majesty uphold all things, they can work honestly and faithfully.
By focusing only on personal gain.
By disregarding God's role in their work.
questions.correctAnswer: By trusting that God’s strength and majesty uphold all things, they can work honestly and faithfully.
questions.explanation: Psalms 93:1 highlights God's majesty and strength sustaining the world, encouraging believers to work with integrity and trust in God's provision.

hard.title: Psalms Chapter 93 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Psalms Chapter 93.

questions.question: In Psalms 93:1, the LORD is described as being clothed with majesty and strength. Which Old Testament theme does this imagery most closely relate to?
options: God as a judge seated on the throne
questions.correctAnswer: God as a divine warrior
questions.explanation: Psalms 93:1 presents God girded with strength and majesty, imagery often associated with the divine warrior motif seen in books like Exodus and Isaiah, where God is portrayed as a conqueror who establishes order.

questions.question: The phrase 'the world also is stablished, that it cannot be moved' in Psalms 93:1 reflects what ancient Near Eastern concept?
options: The cosmic order established by God
questions.correctAnswer: The cosmic order established by God
questions.explanation: The verse speaks to the stability of the world under God's reign, reflecting the ancient Near Eastern idea of cosmic order (often in contrast to chaotic waters), emphasizing God's sovereign power over creation.

questions.question: In Psalms 93:2, 'Thy throne is established of old: thou art from everlasting.' This eternal throne imagery can be seen as a foreshadowing of which New Testament theme?
options: The coming of the Holy Spirit
questions.correctAnswer: The eternal kingship of Christ
questions.explanation: The eternal throne described in Psalms 93:2 prefigures the New Testament emphasis on Christ's eternal reign as King (e.g., Revelation 11:15), highlighting God's unending sovereignty.

questions.question: The floods lifting up their voice and waves in Psalms 93:3 symbolize what in the ancient Near Eastern worldview?
questions.correctAnswer: Chaotic forces opposing divine order
questions.explanation: In Psalms 93:3, floods and waves represent chaotic waters, a common symbol in ancient Near Eastern texts for forces opposing God's established order, reflecting the theme of God's sovereignty over chaos.

questions.question: According to Psalms 93:4, how is the LORD described in relation to the mighty waves of the sea?
questions.correctAnswer: Mightier than their noise
questions.explanation: Psalms 93:4 asserts God's superiority over the tumultuous waves, emphasizing His unmatched power and control over nature and chaos.

questions.question: How does the literary structure of Psalms 93 emphasize the theme of divine kingship?
options: By using parallelism to contrast chaos and order
questions.correctAnswer: By using parallelism to contrast chaos and order
questions.explanation: The psalm uses parallelism, a common Hebrew literary device, to highlight the contrast between chaotic floods and God's established, unmovable reign, reinforcing divine kingship.

questions.question: The term 'holiness' in Psalms 93:5, in Hebrew 'qodesh,' primarily signifies what attribute of God's house?
options: Set apart and pure for God's presence
questions.correctAnswer: Set apart and pure for God's presence
questions.explanation: 'Qodesh' denotes being set apart or holy, indicating that God's house is consecrated for His presence, a theme consistent with temple theology in the Old Testament.

questions.question: True or False: Psalms 93 focuses on the instability of the world and the temporary nature of God's reign.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Psalms 93 emphasizes the stability of the world and the eternal nature of God's reign (Psalms 93:1-2), contrasting with any notion of instability or temporariness.

questions.question: Which literary device is predominant in Psalms 93:3-4 when describing the floods and the LORD's might?
questions.correctAnswer: Personification
questions.explanation: The floods are described as lifting up their voice and waves (Psalms 93:3), attributing human-like actions to natural elements, which is personification.

questions.question: The phrase 'Thy testimonies are very sure' in Psalms 93:5 is best understood as referring to what aspect of God?
questions.correctAnswer: God's faithful and reliable promises
questions.explanation: The 'testimonies' refer to God's trustworthy laws or promises, which are dependable and eternal, as stated in Psalms 93:5.

questions.question: In the context of Psalms 93, how might the 'throne' established of old relate to the Davidic covenant in the Old Testament?
options: It symbolizes the eternal kingship promised to David's lineage
It refers only to the earthly throne in Jerusalem
It is unrelated to any covenant
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes the eternal kingship promised to David's lineage
questions.explanation: The eternal throne in Psalms 93:2 echoes the Davidic covenant (2 Samuel 7), where God promises an everlasting kingdom to David's descendants, linking divine kingship with messianic hope.

questions.question: The imagery of God girding Himself with strength in Psalms 93:1 can be compared to which Old Testament passage that uses similar warrior motifs?
questions.correctAnswer: Isaiah 59:17
questions.explanation: Isaiah 59:17 describes God putting on righteousness as a breastplate and a helmet of salvation, paralleling the warrior imagery of Psalms 93:1 where God is girded with strength.

questions.question: The reference to mighty waves and floods in Psalms 93 can be seen as a typological foreshadowing of what New Testament concept?
options: Christ's triumph over chaos and sin
The coming of the Holy Spirit at Pentecost
questions.correctAnswer: Christ's triumph over chaos and sin
questions.explanation: The imagery of God ruling over chaotic waters (Psalms 93:3-4) foreshadows Christ's victory over sin and death, as He brings order and salvation, a theme developed in the New Testament.

questions.question: The phrase 'holiness becometh thine house' in Psalms 93:5 conveys what about the nature of the temple in ancient Israel?
options: It must be a place of purity and reverence
It should be open to all without restriction
It primarily serves as a royal palace
It is a marketplace for trade
questions.correctAnswer: It must be a place of purity and reverence
questions.explanation: Psalms 93:5 stresses that God's house (the temple) is to be characterized by holiness, emphasizing purity and sanctity required for God's dwelling place.

questions.question: What is the significance of the repeated emphasis on God's unchanging reign in Psalms 93 for the psalm's original audience?
options: It provided assurance of God's sovereignty amid political instability
It encouraged them to rebel against foreign rulers
It suggested that the world was chaotic and uncontrolled
It focused on the agricultural cycles
questions.correctAnswer: It provided assurance of God's sovereignty amid political instability
questions.explanation: Given the historical context of Israel facing threats and exile, Psalms 93 reassures the faithful that God's reign is eternal and unshaken (Psalms 93:1-2), offering hope and stability.

theological.title: Psalms Chapter 93 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Psalms Chapter 93 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Psalms 93:1, how is the LORD described in relation to majesty and strength?
options: Clothed with majesty and strength, girded with power
Weak and humble, dependent on creation
Distant and unapproachable, silent in power
questions.correctAnswer: Clothed with majesty and strength, girded with power
questions.explanation: Psalms 93:1 states that the LORD reigneth and is clothed with majesty and strength, girding Himself with power. This emphasizes God's sovereign and majestic nature, consistent with Isaiah 6:1, Revelation 19:6, 1 Chronicles 29:11, Habakkuk 3:4, and Exodus 15:6.

questions.question: What does Psalms 93:2 teach about the nature of God's throne?
options: Thy throne is established of old; thou art from everlasting
Thy throne is temporary and will be replaced
Thy throne is hidden and unknown
Thy throne is earthly and mortal
questions.correctAnswer: Thy throne is established of old; thou art from everlasting
questions.explanation: Verse 2 affirms the eternal nature of God's reign and throne, highlighting His unchangeable and everlasting sovereignty. This aligns with Hebrews 13:8, Daniel 7:9, Psalm 90:2, Revelation 4:2-3, and Isaiah 40:28.

questions.question: What imagery is used in Psalms 93:3 to describe natural forces, and how do they relate to God?
options: The floods lift up their voice and waves, showing nature’s power under God
The sun and moon are silent witnesses to God's judgment
The mountains bow in fear before human rulers
The wind is the only force that obeys God
questions.correctAnswer: The floods lift up their voice and waves, showing nature’s power under God
questions.explanation: Psalms 93:3 uses the imagery of floods lifting their voice and waves to symbolize chaotic natural forces, emphasizing that even these mighty forces are subject to God's sovereign power. See Job 38:8-11, Jeremiah 5:22, Nahum 1:3, Psalm 65:7, and Matthew 8:26.

questions.question: How does Psalms 93:4 describe God's might in comparison to natural phenomena?
options: The LORD on high is mightier than the noise of many waters and mighty waves
God is quieter than the stillness of a desert
God is less powerful than the roaring sea
God is equal in power to the storms
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD on high is mightier than the noise of many waters and mighty waves
questions.explanation: This verse affirms God's supreme power over all creation, even over the tumultuous and overwhelming forces of nature, consistent with Job 26:12, Psalm 29:3-4, Isaiah 51:15, Revelation 21:15, and Nahum 1:4.

questions.question: What is said about God's testimonies and His house in Psalms 93:5?
options: Thy testimonies are very sure; holiness becometh thine house forever
God’s laws are uncertain and His house is unclean
God’s promises are temporary and His house is desolate
God’s deeds are hidden and His house is forgotten
questions.correctAnswer: Thy testimonies are very sure; holiness becometh thine house forever
questions.explanation: Verse 5 emphasizes the trustworthiness of God's testimonies and the eternal holiness of His dwelling, aligning with Exodus 15:11, Psalm 111:7-8, 1 John 5:7, Hebrews 12:28, and Revelation 21:27.

questions.question: Which attribute of God is primarily highlighted by the description 'He is clothed with majesty' in Psalms 93:1?
questions.correctAnswer: God’s sovereignty and kingly authority
questions.explanation: Being 'clothed with majesty' portrays God's sovereign and regal nature, His kingship over all creation, as supported by Psalm 47:2, Isaiah 33:22, Revelation 15:3, Daniel 4:37, and Psalm 145:1-3.

questions.question: What theological truth is conveyed by 'the world also is stablished, that it cannot be moved' in Psalms 93:1?
options: God’s creation is stable and upheld by His power
The world is chaotic and uncontrollable
The world is temporary and fragile
The world exists independently of God
questions.correctAnswer: God’s creation is stable and upheld by His power
questions.explanation: This verse teaches the doctrine of divine providence and God's sustaining power over creation, consistent with Colossians 1:17, Hebrews 1:3, Nehemiah 9:6, Psalm 104:5, and Job 26:7-10.

questions.question: Psalms 93:2 states, 'Thy throne is established of old: thou art from everlasting.' What does this imply about God's nature?
questions.correctAnswer: God is eternal and unchanging
questions.explanation: This affirms the eternal and immutable nature of God, consistent with Malachi 3:6, James 1:17, Psalm 90:2, Isaiah 40:28, and Revelation 1:8.

questions.question: In Psalms 93:4, the LORD is described as mightier than 'the noise of many waters.' What biblical theme does this imagery reinforce?
options: God’s supremacy over chaos and natural forces
The equality of God with creation
The silence of God in times of trouble
questions.correctAnswer: God’s supremacy over chaos and natural forces
questions.explanation: The imagery of waters and waves represents chaotic forces; God's mightiness over them underscores His sovereign control, confirmed in Genesis 1:2-3, Psalm 65:7, Job 38:8-11, Isaiah 51:15, and John 6:16-21.

questions.question: How does Psalms 93:5 characterize the relationship between God's testimonies and holiness?
options: God’s sure testimonies demand holiness, making His house holy forever
God’s testimonies are flawed and holiness is optional
God’s house is unholy despite His testimonies
Holiness is unrelated to God’s testimonies
questions.correctAnswer: God’s sure testimonies demand holiness, making His house holy forever
questions.explanation: This verse connects the certainty of God's word with the eternal holiness appropriate to His dwelling, reinforcing doctrines of divine purity and covenant faithfulness as seen in Leviticus 19:2, 1 Peter 1:16, Psalm 89:34, Hebrews 10:14, and Revelation 4:8.

questions.question: What eschatological hope is suggested by the phrase 'holiness becometh thine house, O LORD, for ever' in Psalms 93:5?
options: God’s eternal dwelling will be perfectly holy and unchanging
God’s house will be destroyed in the end times
God will abandon holiness in the future
God’s holiness is temporary and incomplete
questions.correctAnswer: God’s eternal dwelling will be perfectly holy and unchanging
questions.explanation: The verse points to the eternal and perfect holiness of God’s dwelling place, reflecting New Testament hope in the new heavens and new earth (Revelation 21:27), the eternal temple (Isaiah 60:13), and Hebrews 12:22-24.

questions.question: Which Christological truth can be inferred from Psalms 93:2's assertion that God’s throne is 'of old' and that He is 'from everlasting'?
options: The Messiah shares in God’s eternal nature and kingship
The Messiah is a temporal human king
The Messiah’s reign is temporary and limited
The Messiah is unrelated to God’s throne
questions.correctAnswer: The Messiah shares in God’s eternal nature and kingship
questions.explanation: The eternal throne correlates with the messianic kingship of Christ, who is eternal (John 1:1-2, Hebrews 1:8, Revelation 19:16, Isaiah 9:7, Psalm 45:6).

questions.question: What apologetic argument does Psalms 93:4 provide against the idea that God is powerless in the face of nature’s forces?
options: God is mightier than the noise of many waters and mighty waves
God is silent during natural disasters
Nature is independent and uncontrollable by God
God is fearful of the sea
questions.correctAnswer: God is mightier than the noise of many waters and mighty waves
questions.explanation: This verse affirms God’s supreme power over natural forces, countering claims of divine impotence, supported by Psalm 107:29, Nahum 1:3, Job 38, Isaiah 40:12-31, and Matthew 8:26.

questions.question: How does Psalms 93:3’s depiction of floods lifting up their voice contribute to a theological understanding of chaos and order?
options: It illustrates chaos in creation that is ultimately subject to God’s control
It denies the existence of disorder in nature
It portrays God as part of the chaotic elements
It suggests creation is autonomous from God
questions.correctAnswer: It illustrates chaos in creation that is ultimately subject to God’s control
questions.explanation: The floods symbolize chaotic forces, but the chapter’s context shows God’s sovereignty over them, consistent with Genesis 1:2-10, Psalm 74:13-14, Jeremiah 5:22, Job 38:11, and Isaiah 51:10.

questions.question: What aspect of God’s character is underscored by the phrase 'Thy testimonies are very sure' in Psalms 93:5?
questions.correctAnswer: God’s faithfulness and reliability
questions.explanation: This verse highlights the trustworthiness of God’s word, foundational for Christian doctrine, as echoed in Numbers 23:19, 2 Timothy 2:13, Psalm 119:89, Hebrews 6:18, and Titus 1:2.
